G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 and G.L. c. 218, § 19 because the events giving rise to this Complaint occurred at the Property located in Worcester, Massachusetts, and the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of this Court.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 and G.L. c. 218, § 19 because the events giving rise to this Complaint occurred at the Property located in Worcester, Massachusetts, and the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of this Court.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential landlord in Massachusetts covenants that tenants shall have the quiet enjoyment of the premises free from substantial interference.

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 289 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that a landlord’s failure to address conditions materially affecting habitability constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to take available measures to remedy serious, crime-related conditions in common areas can constitute a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. The opinion explains that if the landlord “failed to take any action or inadequate action” to remove persons engaged in unlawful activity, thereby permitting a condition that substantially interfered with the tenancies, the covenant is breached. This fits within “conditions materially affecting habitability” and thus supports the proposition that such failures can amount to a breach of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … We conclude that the judge erred in granting summary judgment for the defendant on the plaintiffs’ claim of violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that a landlord’s failure to address conditions materially affecting habitability constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely links statutory and common-law quiet enjoyment with the landlord’s duty to maintain sanitary, habitable conditions. The court explains that § 14 and the covenant of quiet enjoyment protect tenants from serious interferences with their tenancy, and holds Gem liable under § 14 precisely because it violated its duty to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions, allowing repeated flooding that interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment. This aligns with the proposition that failure to address conditions materially affecting habitability constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 429.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that an ongoing rodent infestation represents a material breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 429.support_reasoning: The opinion does not address rodent infestation or habitability/quiet enjoyment in that context. It concerns snow and ice on exterior stairs, and the quiet enjoyment discussion is limited to stating that negligence is a prerequisite for recovery under G.L. c. 186, § 14. Nothing in the case holds or suggests that an ongoing rodent infestation constitutes a material breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, so it cannot be cited for that proposition.
*McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth.*, 429.relevant_excerpt: We reject the plaintiff’s contention that she is entitled to a new trial based on her claims that the defendant violated the lease and the covenant of quiet enjoyment, G. L. c. 186, § 14. Negligence is a prerequisite for recovery under both theories. See Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997) (showing of negligence is required for recovery under quiet enjoyment statute)… The jury’s determination that the defendant was not negligent precludes the possibility that the directed verdicts on these claims constitute a basis for a new trial.

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that an ongoing rodent infestation represents a material breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with loss of heat and hot water as material breaches of the implied warranty of habitability and discusses rent abatement, not the covenant of quiet enjoyment. It does not mention rodents, infestations, or quiet enjoyment at all, nor does it characterize any such condition as a material breach of that covenant. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority that ongoing rodent infestation is a material breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability.”
